Hydroponic Gardening: Another option is to use hydroponics to grow plants without soil. This can be done using a variety of systems such as wick systems, nutrient film technique (NFT) systems, or deep water culture (DWC) systems. These systems use water and nutrients to grow plants, so you don't need to dig into the ground.

Raised Garden Beds: If the ground is too hard to dig into, you can create raised garden beds. These can be made from a variety of materials such as wood, stone, or even repurposed old shipping containers. You can then fill the beds with soil and plant a variety of plants, flowers, or vegetables.

Container Gardening: Another option is to use containers to grow plants. This can be done using a variety of materials such as plastic, metal, or even repurposed old bathtubs. You can then fill the containers with soil and plant a variety of plants, flowers, or vegetables.

Indoor Gardening: If the ground is too hard to dig into, you can create an indoor garden. This can be done using a variety of systems such as grow lights, hydroponics, or even aeroponics. You can then plant a variety of plants, flowers, or vegetables in your indoor garden.

Permaculture Gardening: Another option is to use permaculture principles to create a garden. This can involve using natural materials such as logs, rocks, or even old tires to create raised beds or swales. You can then plant a variety of plants, flowers, or vegetables in your permaculture garden.
